options.label: C

options.text: It is a type of logical fallacy that is not related to probability.

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a statement that is not related to probability.

options.label: C
options.text: The two statements are mutually exclusive.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where people tend to find statements with multiple conditions more believable than the individual conditions on their own.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not familiar with probability.

options.text: Because they are not interested in statistics.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the conjunction fallacy is observed in real-life situations?

options.label: B
options.text: A type of logical fallacy that is not related to probability.

options.label: C
options.text: A statistical concept that is not observed in real-life situations.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of probability that is not related to statistics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key takeaway from the example about Lucy?

options.label: A
options.text: The likelihood of a story being true can never be greater than the probability that its least likely component is true.

options.label: B
options.text: The second statement is more likely to be true than the first statement.

options.label: C
options.text: The first statement is more likely to be true than the second statement.

options.label: D
options.text: The two statements are mutually exclusive.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the conjunction fallacy a problem in statistics?

options.text: Because it is a type of logical fallacy that is not related to probability.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a statistical concept that is not observed in real-life situations.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it occurs when people tend to find statements with multiple conditions more believable than the individual conditions on their own.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a type of probability that is not related to statistics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the conjunction fallacy and the probability of an event?

options.label: A
options.text: The likelihood of an event is never affected by the conjunction fallacy.

options.label: B
options.text: The conjunction fallacy always increases the likelihood of an event.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The dangers of mixing drugs - Céline Valéry

multiple-choice.question: What is a drug interaction?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition where a person's body is not able to process a medication.

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of two or more substances that causes different effects than either would individually.

options.label: C
options.text: A side effect of a medication that is not listed on the label.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where a person's body is allergic to a medication.

options.label: A
options.text: Blood thinners and aspirin interacting to cause internal bleeding.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Cocaine and heroin interacting to cause respiratory failure.

options.label: D
options.text: Saint John's Wort interacting with medications to cause faster metabolism.

options.label: A
options.text: Grapefruit juice interacting with statins to cause kidney failure.

options.label: B
options.text: Cocaine and heroin interacting to cause respiratory failure.

options.label: C
options.text: Saint John's Wort interacting with medications to cause metabolism.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the concentration of statins in the bloodstream.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the concentration of Acetaminophen in the bloodstream.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the metabolism of medications.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the concentration of medications in the bloodstream.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not aware of the game's rules

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the 2/3 game?

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Hawking's black hole paradox explained - Fabio Pacucci

multiple-choice.question: What is the black hole information paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: A paradox that arises from the idea that information about an object that falls into a black hole is lost forever.

options.label: B
options.text: A paradox that threatens to unravel the fields of general relativity and quantum mechanics.

options.label: C
options.text: A problem that arises from the concept of quantum information.

multiple-choice.question: What is quantum information?

options.label: A
options.text: Information that is visible to the naked eye.

options.label: B
options.text: The properties of particles that make up an object, such as their position, velocity, and spin.

options.label: C
options.text: Information that is encoded on the surface of a black hole.

options.label: D
options.text: Information that is lost forever when an object falls into a black hole.

multiple-choice.question: What is the event horizon?

options.label: A
options.text: The boundary of the observable universe.

options.label: B
options.text: The surface of a black hole where the laws of physics break down.

options.label: C
options.text: The point of no return around a black hole.

options.label: D
options.text: The surface of a black hole where information is encoded.

multiple-choice.question: What is Hawking radiation?

options.label: A
options.text: The radiation emitted by a black hole as it evaporates.

options.label: B
options.text: The information encoded on the surface of a black hole.

options.label: C
options.text: The point of no return around a black hole.

options.label: D
options.text: The boundary of the observable universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the holographic principle?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that the boundary of the observable universe is a 2D surface encoded with information about real, 3D objects.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that information is encoded on the surface of a black hole.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that the laws of physics break down at the event horizon.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that information is lost forever when an object falls into a black hole.

multiple-choice.question: What is the unified theory of everything?

options.label: A
options.text: A theory that combines general relativity and quantum mechanics.

options.label: B
options.text: A theory that explains the holographic principle.

options.label: C
options.text: A theory that explains the event horizon.

options.label: D
options.text: A theory that will naturally solve the information paradox.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the black hole information paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: It threatens to unravel the fields of general relativity and quantum mechanics.

options.label: B
options.text: It has led to a range of possible solutions, including the holographic principle.

options.label: C
options.text: It has led to a greater understanding of the laws of physics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between general relativity and quantum field theory?

options.label: A
options.text: They are two separate theories that describe different physical phenomena.

options.label: B
options.text: They are two theories that are difficult to combine.

options.label: C
options.text: They are two theories that are fundamentally incompatible.

options.label: D
options.text: They are two theories that are interchangeable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the event horizon?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the point of no return around a black hole.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the surface of a black hole where information is encoded.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the boundary of the observable universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of the information paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: It will lead to a greater understanding of the laws of physics.

options.label: B
options.text: It will lead to a unified theory of everything.

options.label: C
options.text: It will lead to a new understanding of reality.
